feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:24PM CDT until October 16 at 6:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
At 624 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 10 miles southwest of St. Francis, moving northeast at 45 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
Locations impacted include... St. Francis and Wheeler.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cheyenne, KS

cap:parameter.value: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 645 PM CDT FOR WESTERN CHEYENNE COUNTY IN NORTHWESTERN KANSAS

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:21PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
At 620 PM CDT/520 PM MDT/, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7 miles northeast of Imperial, moving northeast at 35 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and nickel size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Wallace, Elsie, Wanamaker State Wildfire Management Area, and Grainton.
This includes Highway 61 between mile markers 43 and 48.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Perkins; Lincoln; Chase; Hayes

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT SOUTHEASTERN PERKINS... NORTHEASTERN CHASE...SOUTHWESTERN LINCOLN AND NORTHWESTERN HAYES COUNTIES THROUGH 700 PM CDT/600 PM MDT/

* WHERE...Delaware, Fairfield, Hocking, and Licking Counties.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 7:08PM EDT until October 17 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding. For the High Rip Current Risk, dangerous rip currents expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Broward County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Friday morning. For the High Rip Current Risk, from this evening through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Broward County

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued October 16 at 6:03PM CDT until October 16 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
FFWMAF
The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... East Central Jeff Davis County in southwestern Texas...
* Until 900 PM CDT.
* At 603 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated slow moving thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain are estimated to have fallen in the past hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Star Mountain and Highway 17 between Toyahvale and Fort Davis.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jeff Davis, TX

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:03PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary: Areas of fog will reduce visibility to one quarter mile or less from the Turtle Mountains through the James River Valley this evening. Motorists should be prepared for rapidly changing conditions and use extra caution traveling. Use low beam headlights and be extra cautious at intersections and railroad crossings. The fog is expected to dissipate by midnight.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rolette; Pierce; Sheridan; Wells; Foster; Kidder; Stutsman; La Moure

cap:parameter.value: AREAS OF FOG FROM THE TURTLE MOUNTAINS THROUGH THE JAMES RIVER VALLEY THIS EVENING

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 16 at 2:39PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
ESFAFC
As of 2:30PM this afternoon the Snow River has crested due to the Glacier Dammed Lake release. Water levels on the Snow River are currently dropping.
Water levels at the Kenai River at Cooper Landing will continue to rise through Saturday, but will stay below bankfull stage.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Skilak Lake; Interior Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:24PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Clear skies and calm winds overnight will lead to efficient cooling, dropping temperatures into the mid to upper 30s across the typical valley cold spots. Patchy frost development is possible in the aforementioned areas late tonight into early Friday morning.
Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation and plants may be killed if left uncovered. Take steps now to protect tender plants from the cold.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Elliott; Morgan; Johnson; Wolfe; Magoffin; Floyd; Breathitt; Knott; Perry; Letcher; Martin; Pike

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:13PM PDT until October 19 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:01PM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves.
* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak during Friday evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday morning. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are possible late Sunday into early Monday.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 5:52PM EDT until October 16 at 9:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...The lower Cape Fear River including downtown Wilmington and southward.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Portions of Battleship Road and USS North Carolina Road observe minor coastal flooding up to one half foot in depth. In downtown Wilmington, a block of Water Street observes minor flooding up to one quarter foot in depth.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland New Hanover

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM EDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 5:51PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Areas along the beaches, Pamlico Sound, and adjacent tidal creeks.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage (ocean and soundside). Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding. Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around high tide.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ocracoke Island

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT FRIDAY

* WHERE...Areas along the lower Neuse River, Pamlico, Core and Back Sounds, and adjacent tidal creeks.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Carteret

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 5:51PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Hatteras Island.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Friday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding. Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hatteras Island

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 4:31PM CDT until October 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southwest Nebraska, including the following county, Red Willow.
* WHEN...Until 700 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 431 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... McCook.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Red Willow, NE

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM CDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued October 16 at 2:16PM PDT until October 17 at 10:00AM PDT by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Areas of patchy fog developing overnight becoming more dense and widespread into Friday morning. 50 to 60 percent chance for visibilities down to one quarter mile in dense fog.
* WHERE...Caruthers - San Joaquin - Selma, Delano-Wasco-Shafter, Fresno-Clovis, Hanford - Corcoran - Lemoore, Merced - Madera - Mendota, Planada - Le Grand - Snelling, and Visalia - Porterville - Reedley.
* WHEN...From 5 AM to 10 AM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Merced - Madera - Mendota; Planada - Le Grand - Snelling; Caruthers - San Joaquin - Selma; Fresno-Clovis; Delano-Wasco-Shafter; Hanford - Corcoran - Lemoore; Visalia - Porterville - Reedley

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:16PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY EVENING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:10PM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.summary:

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 3:59PM EDT until October 17 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle Keys, minor flooding will be most pronounced around the time of high tide. In the Upper Keys, little relief is expected, even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 3:46PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.
* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 7.3 feet Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 11:02AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A pair of light disturbances will impact the Interior, bringing light snowfall throughout the evening tonight through the weekend. Accumulations of 1-3 inches of snow are expected through this weekend with higher amounts in higher elevations and areas near Healy.
Due to the colder temperatures setting in, this could bring our first permanent snowpack for some areas. Snowfall is expected to accumulate on roadways, making travel conditions difficult at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Tonight Through This Weekend

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:48AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 AM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.2 feet through late week, falling to 3.1 feet this weekend. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 15 at 1:03PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
ESFAFC
The Snow Glacier Dammed Lake is releasing. At this time, we do not expect water levels to reach flood stage on the Snow River, but an additional 1 foot rise of water levels is likely through Friday.
As of 12:45PM, the current water level at Cooper Landing is 10.0 feet. Water levels on Kenai Lake and the Upper Kenai River are expected to rise another half foot, cresting on Friday below flood stage.
There is always uncertainty with Glacier Dam Lake releases. Residents living around Kenai Lake should monitor conditions and prepare for rising water levels.
This statement will be updated daily as more information is available.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Skilak Lake; Interior Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 10:16AM CDT until October 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Dakota...
James River near Stratford affecting Brown and Spink Counties.
.For sites with a river forecast, the forecast includes precipitation through the next 48 hours. Any future precipitation could affect the forecasts.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...James River near Stratford.
* WHEN...Until Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Significant amounts of agricultural lands begin flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 14.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday was 14.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to continue a slow fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brown, SD; Spink, SD

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SUNDAY EVENING
